item.title: Gallery
item.description: Below are some examples of analysis carried out with pygplates. Below each image is a link to a jupyter notebook that illustrates the steps involved for each example. Code and source data can be downloaded for you to try each example yourself. Load CSV Data and Reconstruct View notebook Reconstruct Features to Birth Time View notebook Motion Paths View notebook Flowlines View notebook Convergence Velocities - Single Point View notebook

item.title: Tutorials
item.description: A set of Tutorials are available on github in the form of jupyter notebooks.

item.title: Useful Links
item.description: // NOTEBOOK CONFIGURATION import notebook from "https://api.observablehq.com/@siwill22/platetectonics-draggable.js"; const target = document.querySelector("#visual"); const renders = { "viewof reconstructionModel": "reconstructionModel", "viewof reconstructionTime": "reconstructionTime", "canvas": "div.fullwidth", }; // BOILERPLATE import {Inspector, Runtime} from "https://unpkg.com/@observablehq/notebook-runtime@1.2.0?module"; for (let i in renders) { let s = renders[i], a = s.match(/^\w+/); if (a) { renders[i] = document.createElement(a[0]); target.appendChild(renders[i]); if (a = s.match(/\.(\w+)$/)) renders[i].className = a[1]; } else renders[i] = document.querySelector(renders[i]); } Runtime.load(notebook, (variable) = { if (renders[variable.

item.title: Useful Links
item.description: GPlates Using pygplates requires some knowledge of GPlates - for example, concepts such as rotation models reconstructable features resolved topological polygons Introductory resources for newcomers can be found in the GPlates User Manual and the GPlates tutorials Data No data files are included with the pygplates download, so to get started you’ll need to either provide your own files or start with the files from one of the sources listed below (both GPlates and pygplates are agnostic of the reconstruction model used - the main requirement is that the reconstructions are contained in the file formats that GPlates/pygplates can recognise).

item.title: What is pygplates?
item.description: GPlates is open source software for working with plate tectonic reconstructions. It has a graphical user interface that allows interactive viewing and modification of reconstructions. pygplates is a python API for GPlates. Basically, a python toolbox for coding plate tectonic analysis. There is no graphical interface - the idea is to write python code to automate tasks and perform novel analyses that would be repetitive or impossible within the GPlates GUI.
